subject_as_recorded: Jewish law|Jewish law--interpretation and construction|Jewish doctrine
note: Binding: 19th-century binding|Binding: medieval Hebrew binding fragment beneath endpaper.|Provenance: Purchased by Adolph Sutro from the estate of Moses W. Shapira in 1884. Likely of Yemenite Jewish provenance, but how Shapira acquired his materials is otherwise unknown. Inherited by Adolph Sutro's daughter Emma Sutro Merritt upon his death and donated by her to the California State Library in 1913.|Contains a table of contents, indicating that the present volume contains (or ought to contain) the Third Book of the Mishneh Torah,"Sefer Zemanim" ("The Book of Appointed Times"), relating to laws pertaining to the Jewish festivals, inc. The Sabbath, Passover, Tabernacles, etc.|On fol. 215v, there is a declaration in Judeo-Arabic, a sort of deed of conveyance, transferring ownership of the codex to another party.|This manuscript has been catalogued several times: on fol. 1r, "Cat. S. Roubin Ms. 95 106" refers to one such catalogue and indicates that the number has been changed; on the left "MS. 107 106."
acknowledgments: Identified and described by Dr. Daniel Frank.

subject_as_recorded: Accordian fold books|Manuscripts, Thai|Buddhist literature, Thai|Illumination of books and manuscripts, Thai
physical_description: Extent: 1 volume (156 panels); paper, color illustrations, illuminations; 12 x 37 cm
note: Decoration: Miniatures painted on end panels, some gilt.|Binding: Blind tooled dark brown pasteboards, folded concertina-style|Provenance: Donated to the California State Library by Claude Settlemire, approximately 1960s.

title_as_recorded: Antiphonary|Antiphonarium simul et hymnariu[m] chorale : juxta breviarum romanum transcriptu[m] ad ussum Fratum Minorum Discalceatorum huius Almae Provinciae S. Didaci Strictioris Observantiae Regularis S. P. N. S. Francisci in hoc Conventu Sanctae Mariae Angelorum de Ocholoposco : commorantium tertia pars
subject_as_recorded: Liturgical books|Antiphonaries|Antiphonaries--Manuscripts|Antiphonaries (Service books)|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)--Mexico|Illumination of books and manuscripts, Mexican
former_owner_as_recorded: Convent of Santa María de los Ángeles de Churubusco (de Ocholoposco)|Adolph Sutro (1830-1898)
physical_description: Extent: 111 leaves; vellum, paper, illuminations; 46 x 33 cm or less, bound to 48 x 34 cm
note: Binding: Full contemporary leather binding, gilt-tooled borders and spine panels, and arabesque motifs; metal corner pieces with arabesque motifs, metal center piece with floral motif, and two metal clasp hooks on fore-edge both covers; lower fore-edge clasp and lower left corner piece on left cover missing;|Binding: multiple pages detached from spine; spine fragile with wear on endcaps and stations visible.|Leaf measurements and support varies: fols. 1-101 : vellum ; 46 x 33 cm; fols. 102-107 : paper ; 45 x 29 cm; fols. 108-110 : paper ; 41 x 30 cm ; fol. 111 : paper ; 46 x 31 cm|Provenance: Owned by the Convent of Santa María de los Ángeles de Churubusco (de Ocholoposco)|Franciscan antiphonary with hymns containing the antiphons and hymns for the Propria sanctorum selected and composed from the Roman Breviary transcribed for the use of Discalced Franciscans of the Province of San Diego de México. The province of San Diego de México was an independent province of Observant (Discalced) Franciscans established in Mexico City in 1599 and closed in 1908.|Puebla de Zaragoza was known as Angelopolis, or Civis Angelorum.|The manuscript is one of three original volumes, being the third part.
acknowledgments: Identified and described by Dr. Daniel Gullo.

physical_description: Extent: 142 leaves; paper; 201 x 78 mm bound to 203 x 90 mm
note: Layout: 1 column|Script: Humanistic cursive|Script: Cursive gothic|Binding: Bound, s. XVI, in the original pasteboard wrapper in notarial style with later note on the front cover "Scriptum ca. seculo XII."|Layout, ff. 1-140v: Gatherings 1, 8-10 of 14 leaves, all others of 12; reinforcing strip from notarial document in gutter of innermost bifolium; quires signed with letter of alphabet on last verso, repeated catchword-like on facing recto. Frame ruled in lead.|Provenance: Ownership notes, mainly illegible, inside front cover,". . . Ambroggio 1523 ad oct. A<?> ... Salus..." and " 692." De Ricci states that the volume was "last in Germany." Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.|Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 26 n. 4.|ff. 1-140v: ff. 1-11, index; ff. 11v-12 non-indexed recipes in a different hand; ff. 12v-13 blank; ff. 14-16, non-indexed recipes, some in Latin; f. 16v, table of weight measurements; ff. 17-140v main text.
acknowledgments: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

production_date_as_recorded: First half of the fifteenth century
physical_description: Extent: fol. 1; parchment; 110 x 62 mm
note: Layout: 1 column, 21 lines|Script: Humanist script|Decoration: Full-surround trompe l’oiel gold-ground borders with floral infill on recto and a trailing gold/black rope/cord on the verse bottom margin|Pagination "2" in upper margin of verso, on left in black and in the center in black in a grey box.|Provenance: The intact MS was offered by Sam Fogg (Cat. 14) in 1991, and it was ultimately broken by Ferrini sometime thereafter (possibly in cooperation with Fogg and/or others).|Almost certainly a leaf excised from the so-called "Pichon Hours."|The rope/cord borders around the text block is a characteristic of the work of the atelier that produced the Pichon Hours, and there are at least a few other MSS out there (intact and fragmentary) probably produced by the same workshop and sporting the same borders/frames.|This Book of Hours has been credited to an atelier called (by modern scholarship) “the 1520s Hours Workshop”, likely in Paris and under the direction of the Dutch artist Noel Bellemare.|The surviving binding/sewing stations on the edge of the leaf (6 total) would seem to match up with sewing station remains on Pichon Hours folios at Ohio State (Columbus, OH, Ohio State University Rare Books and Manuscripts Library, Spec.Rare.MS.MR.Frag.442) (also 6). The dimensions of the leaves at Ohio State match as well.|Another similar feature is the pagination in black (visible on the verso of this leaf). The pagination there (not foliation; every side is numbered in this MS) reads “2”, so this is likely the first leaf of the MS, which would match up with the textual component: the opening of the Gospel readings.
acknowledgments: Identified and described by Dr. Eric J. Johnson.

physical_description: Extent: paper
note: Layout: 1 column, 25 lines|Script: Sefardic cursive|Colophon on 88r, unable to make out.|Provenance: Purchased by Adolph Sutro from the estate of Moses W. Shapira in 1884. Likely of Yemenite Jewish provenance, but how Shapira acquired his materials is otherwise unknown. Inherited by Adolph Sutro's daughter Emma Sutro Merritt upon his death and donated by her to the California State Library in 1913.
acknowledgments: Identified and described by Dr. Daniel Frank.

physical_description: Extent: 87 leaves; paper; 27 x 16 cm
note: Binding: Type III red leather binding over pasteboards with stamped mandorla and pendants on both covers; some general wear at all edges.|A guide for correspondence and composition written in Persian, composed in India in the 17th century. A collection of sample letters and documents designed as a reference for bureaucratic secretaries in the Mughal Empire.

title_as_recorded: Psalter, diurnal|Psalmi ad horas diurnas, hymni [et] annu[m] [et] ad horas, agenda [de]functo[rum] cu[m] lectioni[bus] [et] laudibus
physical_description: Extent: 79 leaves; parchment; 362 x 256 mm bound to 378 x 270 mm
note: Script: Liturgical gothic book hand|Binding: Bound in stamped leather overs wooden boards with 2 fore edge brass clasps; some gilt tooling.; 15 fore edge tabs to mark major text divisions. Rebound in the 19th century; blind-tooled spine panels with title and "Lat. Ms. on Parch. 15.Cent." in gilt. Marbled pastedowns and flyleaves.|Layout, ff. 1-78v: Gatherings of 8, catchwords present, quire and leaf signatures in letter of the alphabet and roman numeral (out of order in 7th quire); 18 long lines of text.|Provenance: Carthusians of Buxheim; Hugo, Graf von Waldbott-Bassenhim (his sale, Munich, 20 September 1883, lot 2672); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.|Bibliography: Not in De Ricci. Dutschke and Dutschke misattributed De Ricci no. 1 to this manuscript--no. 1 is a 17th-century manuscript.|ff. 1-78v: On ff. 1-46v, psalter; ff. 46v-58, hymns; ff. 58-78v, office for the dead.|Music, ff. 1-78v: On 4-line red staves.
acknowledgments: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

physical_description: Extent: 143 leaves; parchment; 37 x 27 cm
note: Script: Liturgical gothic book hand.|Binding: Bound, s. XVI, in stamped white vellum over wooden boards bevelled to the inside; evidence of 2 fore edge clasps; fore edge leather tabs at major text divisions.|Provenance: On f. 121, rubric for St. John the Baptist "patroni ordinis nostri et ecclesie huius"; Carthusians of Buxheim; in the sale of Hugo, Graf von Waldbott-Bassenheim (Munich, 20 September 1883, lot 2533); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.|Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 26 as n. 3.|ff. 1-143: Contemporary pagination in red roman numerals.|ff. 1-142v; f. 143r-v blank: On ff. 1-110, temporale from Advent to 23rd Sunday after Pentecost; ff. 110-140, sanctorale adds: Francis de Paula, Catherine of Siena, Anthony of Padua, Bonaventure, Agatha, Afra, Bernard, Nicolas of Tolentino, Francis, Bruno, Gallus.|Layout, ff. 1-143: 9 sets of text and 4-line red staves to the page; quires mainly of 8 leaves.|Music, ff. 1-143: Musical notation.
acknowledgments: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

physical_description: Extent: 48 leaves; parchment; 206 x 136 mm bound to 211 x 144 mm
note: Layout: 25 long lines ruled in ink.|Script: Humanistic|Decoration: One inhabited initial on gold ground; bust of a bishop on a red shield carrying the name Alexander inside a green wreath. Border along lower edge of f. 1 of sprays of flowers decorated with gold balls; 2- and 3-line initials alternating in blue and gold with pen flourishing in red and blue respectively; headings in red centered above blocks of text.|Binding: Green vellum.|Provenance: Carlo Archinto of Milan (1669-1732); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.|Provenance: Manuscript accompanied by a letter, dated 23 May 1890, from George Moss (librarian of Sutro) to Rosa Sutro Morbio (1858-1942) which states that her father would like her to have this manuscript and another prayer book (Sutro Library M000099). Donated to the Sutro Library by her son, Carlo Sutro Morbio (1888-1971) about 1970.|Bibliography: Not in De Ricci.|ff. 1r-48v: Scribal colophon, 4. 46r; back pastedown from another manuscript; written surface faces board, making writing only faintly visible.|ff. 1r-46r: ff. 44v-45v, 4 additional letters with preface to Alfonso of Naples; f. 46, letter to Francesco Pellotus of Padua; ownership note. f. 46r; ff. 46v-47v blank; 2 alphabets & excerpts from Sallust and Lucan, signed "A. B" on f. 48r; f. 48v blank.
acknowledgments: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

physical_description: Extent: 135 leaves; paper; ff. 1-38 ; 235 x 167 mm bound to 248 x 183 mm; ff. 39-46 ; 205-210 x 139-149 mm bound to 248 x 183 mm; ff. 47-111 ; 216-219 x 154-160 mm bound to 248 x 183 mm; f. 112 ; 230 x 172 mm bound to 248 x 183 mm; ff. 113-114 ; 214 x 148 mm bound to 248 x 183 mm; ff. 115-135 ; 231 x 173 mm bound to 248 x 183 mm
note: Binding: Bound, s. XIX with labels on spine,"Paschasii De corpore et sanguine Domini" and "Bertoni opera."|Provenance: On f. 1, illegible even under ultra-violet light due to stain,"Iste liber est monachorum <?> deputatus monasterii <sancte Marie ?> <?>." On f. i verso,"14.6.13" written over "A.42000" by Frederic Beecher Perkins during his time as Adolph Sutro's cataloging consultant, about 1894.|Bibliography: Not in De Ricci.|ff. 1-36: On f. 1, Regis adire sacre qui vis sollemnia mense . . . (15 verses spelling "Radbertus levita"); ff. 1-2, dedicatory letter.|ff. 39-135: Terminus post quem provided by texts: f. 132, tipped-in note recording the death of Frater Bonaventura Cesenas, last descendant of Caesaro Bertono, in 1719; ff. 133-134, speech by Pope Innocent in 1666 and a rhyme in Italian of an event in 1686.|ff. 36-135: ff. 36-38, fragment of Peter Damian's Epistola de die iudicii; ff. 39-45v, life of St. Maurus by Maurus Verdoni; ff. 47-111v, sermons in Italian; f. 112v, list of Greek schismatics; ff. 113-114v, Memoriale in first person, signed F. Bonaventura [Bertono] Cesenas Capuccinus;|ff. 115-124, Elucidations against Greek schismatics, signed F. Bonaventura [Bertono] Cesenas Capuccinus; ff. 125-132, Elucidations against Calvinism and Lutheranism, signed F. Bonaventura [Bertono] Cesenas Capuccinus; ff. 133-134, speech by Pope Innocent XI in 1666 and a rhyme in Italian of an event in 1686.|Explicit, ff. 1-36: Quisquis catholicorum recte dominum cuncta creasse de nichilo.|Incipit, ff. 36-38v: Dilectissimo fratri Ade Petrus peccator monachus humilis in domino salutem. Quod me, frater karissime, quid ante mundi creationem fuerit . . .
acknowledgments: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

title_as_recorded: Book of Hours, use of Rome

note: Layout: 14 long lines ruled in ink|Script: Rounded gothic book hand.|Decoration: Four historiated initials.|Binding: Bound, s. XVII, in leather over pasteboards, blind stamped with a rosette surrounding the IHS monogram; evidence of 2 fore edge clasps closing from top to bottom; 3 fore edge tabs; on the front pastedown, a woodcut of the Crucifixion.|Gatherings of 10 leaves, except for the 11th (of 8) and the last two (of 2, counting pastedown)|Provenance: On ff. 105v, 109v-141v, in margins, notes of the Floriani family, 1591-1702, in areas near Bologna (S. Martino in Argile, S. Lorenzo del Castello di Budrio, Dozza; Budrio); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco. Given to his daughter, Rosa Sutro Morbio (1858-1942) in 1890. Donated to the Sutro Library by her son, Carlo Sutro Morbio (1888-1971), about 1970.|Bibliography: Not in De Ricci.|ff. 1-172v: ff. i-iii verso, additions; ff. 1-79, Hours of the BVM; ff. 79v-80v, added prayers; ff. 81-105v, Penitential psalms & litany; ff. 106-108v, rhyming prayer in Italian; ff. 109-165, Office of the Dead; ff. 166-169v, Office of the Cross; ff. 170-172v, added.
acknowledgments: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

Watermarks, ff. 1-370: Briquet 8651.|Provenance: On front pastedown, pressmark,"a.37"; bookplate of Victor Albert George Child-Villiers (1845-1915), Earl of Jersey, Osterley Park; clipping from Sotheby's, lot 56; Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.|Bibliography: Eighth Report of the Royal Commission on Historical Manuscripts, Report and Appendix, Pt. 1(London 1881), p. 100, n. 21. Not in De Ricci.|ff. 1-370; f. 370v blank: Many erasures and corrections as if a draft copy.|Explicit, ff. 1-370; f. 370v blank: Pour l'an mil iiii cent et viii aprez la mort du bon Roy Richard . . .

title_as_recorded: [Dalāʼil al-khayrāt wa-shawāriq al-anwār fī dhikr al-ṣalāh ʻalá al-nabī al-mukhtār ... etc]
title_as_recorded_agr: [دلائل الخيرات وشوارق الانوار في ذكر الصلاة على النبي المختار … الخ]
subject_as_recorded: Islam--Prayers and devotions--early works to 1800|Sufism--Prayers and devotions--early works to 1800|Muḥammad,--Prophet,-- -632--Early works to 1800.
physical_description: Extent: 156 leaves; paper, illuminations; 17 x 11 cm
note: Layout: Leaves 2-143: 9 long lines, gilt border rule around textblock and single-line red border rule around page margins|Layout: Leaf 144: 18 long lines, no border rule|Layout: Leaves 145-156: 8-15 long lines, no border rule|Script: Naskh and nasti'liq script.|Decoration: Illuminated headpieces (gold, shades of pastel pink and blue with white, red, and blue accents) at opening of each of several sections. Paintings with depictions in perspective of al-Masjid al-Ḥarām in Mecca on leaf 31v and Prophet’s mosque (al-Masjid al-Nabawī) in Medina on leaf 32r|Binding: Ottoman stamped leather binding (type II, with flap) — pasteboards covered in red-brown leather, stamped with central scalloped mandorla with pendants and corner pieces, gold painted|Leaves 1 and 2 glued together; some obscured text [manuscript waste?] visible on leaf 1v.|Provenance: No colophon apparent in photos provided. Hand, decoration, etc suggest mid to late 18c Ottoman production.|Provenance: Manuscript inscriptions in ink on flyleaves and leaf 1r, some illegible; "lot 8" visible in pencil on front flyleaf|Illuminated compendium of prayers in Arabic and Turkish including al-Jazūlī's (d.1465) Dalāʼil al-khayrāt — a litany of blessings over the Prophet Muḥammad. Opens with Turkish introduction, followed by prayer to open the prayers of Dalāʼil al-khayrāt, then opening of Dalāʼil al-khayrāt.|Numerous prayer excerpts (some of them identified by title and / or by purpose eg warding off illness) in at least three different hands on endpapers and on otherwise blank folios at close of volume, continuing onto back flyleaf. In one of the same hands, occasional marginalia with excerpts in Arabic and Turkish.|Other marginalia from standard commentaries (such as that of al-Fāsī d.1698) accompany the text of Dalāʼil al-khayrāt|References: Göloğlu, Sabiha. “Depicting the Islamic Pilgrimage Sites: Mecca, Medina, and Jerusalem in Late Ottoman Illustrated Prayer Books,” in Proceedings of the 15th International Congress of Turkish Art, Naples, 14–16 September 2015, edited by Michele Bernardini, Alessandro Taddei and Michael Douglas Sheridan (Ankara: Republic of Turkey Ministry of Culture and Tourism, 2018): 323–338|Göloğlu, Sabiha. “Touching Mecca & Medina: The Dalā’il al-Khayrāt and Devotional Practices,” Khamseen: Islamic Art History Online, published 28 August 2020;Göloğlu, Sabiha. “In Writing and in Sound: The Dalāʾil al-Khayrāt in the Late Ottoman Empire.” Journal of Islamic Manuscripts 12, 3-4 (2021): 433–474
acknowledgments: All description and identification by Dr. Evyn Kropf

physical_description: Extent: paper, illuminations; 160 x 95 mm bound to 162 x 95 mm
note: Binding: Heavy pasteboards covered in painted lacquerwork with floral composition ; doublures with figural depiction.|Provenance: As appears in colophon, copied out by Sayyid ʻAlī (سید علی) with transcription completed 23 Dhū al-Qaʻdah 1258 H [ca 26 December 1842 CE].|Provenance: Lengthy inspection statement in name of Sulaymān Shuʻāʻ al-Dawlah son of Farīdūn Mīrzā (d.1854) son of crown prince ʻAbbās Mīrzā (1789-1833) – سلیمان شعاع الدوله ابن فریدون میرزا ابن عباس میرزا ولی عهد مغفو — on recto of opening folio dated Shaʻbān 1301 H [ca June 1884 CE], accompanied by his seal impression “شعاع الدوله”|Richly illuminated copy of the enormously famous collected poems of the masterful poet Ḥāfiẓ (Khvājah Shams al-Dīn Muḥammad Shīrāzī, d.1390?). Incipit: “الا یا ایها الساقی ادر کاسا وناولها که عشق آسان نمود اول ولی افتاد مشکلها”|Title from statement on recto of opening folio: Dīvān-i Khvājah Ḥāfiẓ دیوان خواجه حافظ
acknowledgments: All description and identification by Dr. Evyn Kropf

physical_description: Extent: 31 leaves; parchment, illuminations; 155 x 107 mm bound to 161 x 115 mm
note: Layout: 1 column, 16 lines|Script: Written in a mature gothic script in black ink|Decoration: Enlarged initials in gold on blue or pink grounds. Fol. 1r has a miniature depicting a burial, surrounded by a foliate border typical of a 15th-c. Flemish book of hours. The border includes a black, three-legged vessel.|Binding: 19th century red levant morocco|Provenance: Purchased by Eugene Sather (1924-1986) at an auction in Los Angeles about 1960. Acquired by the Sutro Library about 1980 or 1990.

subject_as_recorded: Islam--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Calligraphy, Ottoman--Specimens|Calligraphy, Arabic--Specimens|Writing, Arabic--Specimens|Islamic calligraphy--Specimens.|Muḥammad,--Prophet,-- -632--Companions--Early works to 1800|Badr, Battle of, Badr Ḥunayn, Saudi Arabia, 624--Early works to 1800|Muḥammad,--Prophet,-- -632--Companions--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800
physical_description: Extent: 29 leaves; paper, illuminations; 155 x 101 mm bound to 156 x 104 mm
note: Layout: 9 long lines, black, red, and gilt border rule around textblock|Decoration: Illuminated headpiece at opening ; illuminated finispiece with floral designs following colophon with signature of calligrapher.|Binding: Leather over pasteboard (Type III), gilt tooled borders; marbled endpapers; completely split at first gathering|Provenance: Signature of calligrapher in colphon — Ali, from among the students of the famous Ottoman master Mehmet Rasim (= Eğrikapılı Mehmet Râsim Efendi, d.1756). No date of transcription provided. Decoration, dates of master calligrapher, etc suggest early to mid 18th century. Former owner’s mark on opening flyleaf.|Illuminated calligraphic piece employing a text discussing and naming the ṣaḥābah or Companions of the Prophet who took part in the battle of Badr. Compare PUL Islamic Manuscripts, Garrett no. 955Y and PUL Islamic Manuscripts, Garrett no. 1585Y and cf Mach, Yahuda, 4611|Incipit: الحمد لله الذي أشرف ضياء الاسلام بطلعة نبوة سيد الانام Explicit: أبو مسعود البدري أبو مليل أبو الهيثم أبو اليسر وقد تم باليمن والبركة اسماء الصحابة البدريين رضوان الله تعالى عليهم اجمعين آمين
acknowledgments: All description and identification by Dr. Evyn Kropf
